title: Missing Rate Limiting and Account Lockout on Authentication Endpoints
description: The password authentication endpoint (/password/{username}) does not implement any rate limiting or account lockout mechanisms. An attacker can submit unlimited failed authentication attempts without any penalties, restrictions, or delays. This allows for unrestricted brute force attacks against user accounts. The application processes all password submission attempts regardless of quantity or speed, enabling systematic password guessing attacks when combined with knowledge of valid usernames (via user enumeration vulnerabilities).
impact: Attackers can perform unlimited brute force attacks against any user account without throttling or lockout penalties. Combined with the user enumeration vulnerability, an attacker can systematically attempt to crack passwords through automated brute force attacks. Accounts with weak or predictable passwords could be compromised through sustained automated attack attempts. The lack of account lockout also means legitimate users cannot be denied access through account takeover attempts.
evidence:
POC execution results:
- Test: Submitted 20 failed password attempts in rapid succession
- Result: All 20 requests processed with HTTP 302 responses
- No rate limiting (HTTP 429) responses observed
- No throttling delays between requests
- No account lockout triggered
- No "too many attempts" error messages

Command executed:
for i in {1..20}; do curl -s http://localhost:8080/password/test -d "username=test&user_id=10032&password=wrong$i" -H "Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded"; done

POC Output:
=== Rate Limiting and Account Lockout Test ===
Testing: Submitting 20 failed authentication attempts...
Endpoint: http://localhost:8080/password/test

=== Test Results ===
Total Attempts: 20
Successful Responses (HTTP 302): 20
Rate Limited Responses (HTTP 429): 0

VULNERABILITY CONFIRMED: No rate limiting detected!
All 20 requests were processed without throttling.
remediation:
1. Implement rate limiting on the /password/{username} endpoint (e.g., maximum 5 failed attempts per minute per IP address)
2. Implement temporary account lockout after N failed attempts (e.g., 5 failed attempts = 15 minute lockout)
3. Implement progressive delays between failed attempts (exponential backoff)
4. Log all failed authentication attempts for security monitoring and alerting
5. Send email notifications to account owners when multiple failed login attempts occur
6. Implement CAPTCHA after 3 failed attempts to prevent automated attacks
7. Consider implementing IP-based blocking for sources with excessive failed attempts
8. Implement per-username rate limiting in addition to per-IP limiting to prevent distributed attacks
references: OWASP A07:2021 - Identification and Authentication Failures, CWE-307 - Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames, CWE-308 - Use of Single-factor Authentication, CWE-1390 - Weak Authentication
toolCallDescription: Documenting the missing rate limiting and account lockout vulnerability with working POC
